questions.question: A solution gives a blue precipitate with NaOH that turns black on heating. Which cation?
questions.explanation: Cu²⁺ gives blue Cu(OH)₂ with NaOH. On heating: Cu(OH)₂ → CuO (black) + H₂O

questions.question: Which cation produces ammonia gas when warmed with NaOH solution?
questions.explanation: NH₄⁺ + OH⁻ → NH₃(g) + H₂O. The ammonia turns damp red litmus blue.

questions.question: A green solution gives a green precipitate with NaOH that turns brown on standing. Identify.
questions.explanation: Fe²⁺ gives pale green solution and green Fe(OH)₂ precipitate. In air, it oxidizes to brown Fe(OH)₃.

questions.question: Which cation gives a white precipitate with NaOH that dissolves in excess NaOH?
questions.explanation: Zn²⁺ gives white Zn(OH)₂ with NaOH, which dissolves in excess to form [Zn(OH)₄]²⁻.

questions.question: A solution gives a red-brown precipitate with NaOH. With NH₃, it gives the same red-brown precipitate. Which cation?
questions.explanation: Fe³⁺ gives red-brown Fe(OH)₃ with both NaOH and NH₃. The precipitate is insoluble in excess.

questions.question: Which cation gives a white precipitate with NaOH that is insoluble in excess NaOH but dissolves in acids?
questions.explanation: Ca²⁺ gives white Ca(OH)₂ with NaOH, insoluble in excess but soluble in acids: Ca(OH)₂ + 2H⁺ → Ca²⁺ + 2H₂O.

questions.question: A cation gives white precipitate with NaOH soluble in excess. With NH₃, it gives white precipitate soluble in excess. Identify.
questions.explanation: Zn²⁺ gives white Zn(OH)₂ soluble in both excess NaOH (forms [Zn(OH)₄]²⁻) and excess NH₃ (forms [Zn(NH₃)₄]²⁺).

questions.question: Which cation gives no precipitate with NH₃ solution but gives white precipitate with NaOH?
questions.explanation: Ca²⁺ gives white precipitate with NaOH but no precipitate with NH₃ because ammonia solution is weakly alkaline, insufficient to precipitate Ca(OH)₂.
